stream_context.summary: Kaze continues building and greyboxing a late-game area (Course 14), preparing it to hand off to Biobak for final color/texture work. He fixes small gameplay/behavior bugs, debates player routing and optional mechanics (rollable bridge, 8-bit/retro pipe placement), and does major brainstorming for the Mario Paint-themed retro section—landing on a concrete design for a draw-on-canvas minigame with scoring based on pixel matching. He also discusses misconceptions about Expansion Pak requirements and locks in a working name + backstory framing for the ice castle course.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains several documentary-relevant decisions and insights: camera-driven level re-scaling, a clear plan for the Mario Paint retro section (including technical approach), a public timeline expectation for finishing main content in 2025, and naming/backstory work for the ice castle course.

findings.summary: Kaze enlarged a greyboxed area to reduce camera problems and removed an unintended triple-jump skip, accepting the loss of a speedrun-like shortcut in favor of readability and camera stability.
findings.quote: The area needed to be bigger for the sake of the camera. That's one issue I hate in Mario 64 when that happens.

findings.summary: He is sending the current grey, non-final UV-mapped version of the area to Biobak so Biobak can create the final color/texture pass, reflecting their pipeline of Kaze blocking out geometry/gameplay first and art polish happening after.

He describes a dependency chain that blocks “full playability” until later: instant warps require a collision map, which in turn requires the level to be in a more finalized state—so he avoids premature implementation to prevent wasted work.
findings.quote: To make instant warps we need a collision map, and to make a collision map we need the first full level—unless we want to waste a lot of time.

findings.summary: He debugs and tweaks a small enemy/prop (“bump” with googly eyes), discovering the issue is tied to an “eye gravity” behavior and removing that behavior to stop unwanted motion/snapback.

Kaze pushes back on the common ROM-hack assumption that the Expansion Pak is inherently required, saying it was historically used mainly as a convenience due to older tooling and lazy memory management, and that many hacks could be made to run without it with proper memory handling.
findings.quote: The reason ROM hacks used the Expansion Pak is convenience… instead of properly managing my memory, I'm just gonna use the Expansion Pak.

findings.summary: He debates adding/placing a “rollable bridge” and the 8-bit/retro pipe entry, weighing clarity and fun against redundancy because the wing cap can already trivialize traversal; he wants the entry to be visible and legible rather than requiring awkward tech.
findings.quote: I don't want to make players do that… that's too much difficulty.

findings.summary: A HUD bug appears after moving coin UI elements: when Mario takes damage, the egg-coin counter shifts incorrectly (it behaves like the coin counter), indicating a coupling/offset bug in the HUD layout logic after repositioning elements.

For the Course 14 retro section, Kaze reaffirms the plan: this retro section is Mario Paint-themed, and the final retro section in the game will be Mario 64-themed; he considers abandoning Mario Paint for alternatives (Dr. Mario, Paper Mario) but continues toward a Mario Paint solution.
findings.quote: The retro section for this is going to be Mario Paint themed, and then the last retro section is going to be Mario 64 themed.

findings.summary: He gives a concrete progress snapshot: the next area is the last area for Course 14; Course 15 is already about halfway done; after all courses, only three more side levels and three overworld parts remain. He expects finishing main content in 2025 with significant time reserved for polish.
findings.quote: We're almost done with Course 14… I feel like we're definitely gonna finish all the main content in 2025, and then we have a lot of time to polish the game.

findings.summary: He finalizes (for now) the ice castle course name as “Forgotten Fortress,” describing the intended emotional color/vibe of the word “Forgotten” as part of naming philosophy (tone-first naming).
findings.quote: Forgotten already feels cold to me… Forgotten as a word is like dark blue, transparent.

findings.summary: Mario Paint retro section direction becomes concrete: a white void canvas area with a color palette UI and a dotted-line Mario outline on the floor. The player “draws” by walking/painting, possibly using ground pound to fill large areas; the game awards a star when the drawn result is “close enough.”

He outlines an implementation approach for Mario Paint scoring: compare the player’s canvas pixels against a target image (pixel matching / RGB difference). He wants to keep the canvas small for feasibility, targeting ~124x124 RGBA32 (or similar) and building dotted-line source art from N64-era artwork. He flags filling as a key programming challenge.
findings.quote: Do you have a Mario detection algorithm? Yes, I will make one… All of Mario's face will have pixel matching.

findings.summary: Kaze emphasizes a design constraint: he wants to avoid hard-coding camera positions for the Mario Paint section so it still feels like a 3D platforming experience rather than a fixed-view minigame.
findings.quote: I really want to avoid hard-coded camera… I want this to still be a 3D platform.

findings.summary: He briefly documents internal object parameterization (“beeper” parameters controlling rotation direction/axis, speed granularity, and scale) and notes he can add an opacity/alpha parameter easily—showing how custom actor behavior is exposed via configurable params.

biobak.summary: Biobak is positioned as the next-step owner for visual polish: Kaze plans to send the UV-mapped greybox so Biobak can “make the colors pretty.”

zeina.summary: Kaze notes there is still an outside area for the ice castle that Zeina wanted to work on, indicating she has specific ownership/interest in that portion of the level’s art/layout.

key_stories.title: Camera constraints force geometry changes
key_stories.summary: While finishing a greybox section, Kaze expands the play space to prevent camera issues and intentionally removes a triple-jump skip. He’s mildly disappointed about losing the shortcut but treats camera readability as the higher priority for most players.
key_stories.challenge: Keeping platforming readable and fair given Mario 64’s camera limitations in tighter spaces.
key_stories.process: Enlarges the area, adjusts routes, and accepts that some advanced movement exploits will no longer work.
key_stories.outcome: A more camera-stable space ready to be handed off for art polish, at the cost of one known skip.
key_stories.key_quote: The area needed to be bigger for the sake of the camera.

key_stories.title: Debunking the Expansion Pak requirement myth
key_stories.summary: Kaze explains that many ROM hacks “require” the Expansion Pak largely due to old tools and convenience-driven memory practices, not because the content can’t fit otherwise. He frames it as a discipline problem—proper memory management makes non-Expansion Pak builds achievable.
key_stories.challenge: Community assumptions that ambitious N64 hacks must rely on the Expansion Pak.
key_stories.process: Clarifies the historical reasons and implies his decomp-based workflow enables cleaner memory control than legacy ROM-hack pipelines.
key_stories.outcome: Sets an engineering narrative: the team is modernizing the workflow and constraints rather than taking the easy hardware path.
key_stories.key_quote: You could absolutely make Star Road work on the N64 without an Expansion Pak.

key_stories.title: Making Mario Paint work as 3D platforming
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggles to find “platforming potential” in Mario Paint’s modes, briefly considering swapping to Dr. Mario or Paper Mario. He then lands on a Mario Paint canvas concept: a dotted-line Mario outline on the floor, palette selection, and a star awarded via pixel-matching accuracy, while keeping free camera/3D movement.
key_stories.challenge: Turning a non-platformer (Mario Paint) into a fun retro section that still feels like Mario 64.
key_stories.process: Brainstorms multiple interpretations (music-note jumping, canvas platform generation, drawing minigame), rejects fixed-camera solutions, and converges on a draw-on-floor system with scoring thresholds.
key_stories.outcome: A concrete technical + design plan: small RGBA32 canvas (~124x124), dotted-line source art, player painting via movement/ground pounds, and an algorithmic “close enough” check.
key_stories.key_quote: There's just nothing in there that I feel like I can base the platforming on… I want this to still be a 3D platform.

key_stories.title: Naming and framing the ice castle level
key_stories.summary: While showing the in-progress ice castle, Kaze and chat iterate on names until he picks “Forgotten Fortress.” He describes the intended emotional color of the word “Forgotten” and shares the level’s story context: a penguin village at a mountain peak threatened by a monster occupying the castle.
key_stories.challenge: Finding a name that conveys the level’s tone and mystery without sounding generic.
key_stories.process: Rapid iteration on alliterative and synonym-based options; chooses based on vibe and psychological tone rather than literal description.
key_stories.outcome: Working title established alongside a clear narrative hook for the level.
key_stories.key_quote: Forgotten already feels cold to me… like dark blue, transparent.

open_questions.topic: Mario Paint retro section: scoring and UX
open_questions.context: Kaze plans pixel matching against a target image and a “close enough” threshold for awarding a star, using a small canvas (e.g., 124x124 RGBA32) and dotted-line outline art.
questions: What exact metric will determine “close enough” (per-pixel RGB delta sum, masked regions, weighted areas like face outline vs fill)?
Will players see any feedback while drawing (percentage complete, heatmap, score), or only a pass/fail at the end?
How will you prevent/handle players drawing obscene shapes (or is that intentionally allowed/ignored)?
Will the challenge be time-based, accuracy-based, or include multiple stars with different score thresholds?

open_questions.topic: Mario Paint retro section: fill mechanic feasibility
open_questions.context: Kaze expects “programming the filling” to be difficult and considers ground pound filling large areas.
questions: Will the game implement true flood-fill, region stamping, or a simpler mechanic (e.g., paint-by-walking only, plus a large-radius ground-pound brush)?
How will fill interact with the dotted-line outline requirement—does painting over the outline penalize the score?
What performance/memory constraints on N64 most affect implementing fill and frequent pixel updates?

open_questions.topic: Art pipeline for dotted-line outline Mario
open_questions.context: Kaze needs a target Mario face that can be converted into dotted lines and simplified colors suitable for the canvas minigame.
questions: Who will produce the final Mario face art and dotted-line conversion—Kaze, Biobak, or Zeina?
Will the outline be an overlay mask separate from the player paint layer, or baked into the target image and excluded from scoring?
What style reference will you lock to (specific N64-era marketing art, Mario Paint UI look, or a custom simplified palette)?

open_questions.context: Kaze delays making the area fully playable because instant warps require collision maps, which he prefers to generate after the level is more complete.
questions: What does your current toolchain for collision generation look like in the decomp workflow (Blender export, custom scripts, manual fixes)?
What makes instant warps dependent on collision in your implementation—warp trigger placement, camera cuts, or streaming/room transitions?
At what stage do you consider a level “complete enough” to lock collision and warps without causing rework?

open_questions.topic: HUD coupling bug (egg coins shifting on damage)
open_questions.context: After moving coin UI to the top corner, the egg-coin counter moves the wrong way when Mario takes damage, suggesting shared offsets with the coin counter animation.
questions: Is the egg-coin counter reusing the same transform/animation routine as the standard coin counter, and should it be decoupled?
Do you have a HUD layout system yet (anchors, relative positioning), or are these hardcoded coordinates that keep drifting as features get added?
Could this bug reveal broader HUD tech debt that might affect late-game polish?
